qas.question: What type of campus did Northwestern begin construction of during Walter Dill Scott's presidency?
What was the orginal name for Northwestern's Ryan Field?
What merger was proposed and rejected in 1933?

answers.text: Northwestern with the University of Chicago

qas.question: What was Northwestern one of the first six universities in the U.S. to establish in the 1920's?

answers.text: a Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps (NROTC)

qas.question: What first-ever game did Northwestern host in 1939?

answers.text: NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship

qas.question: What type of campus did Northwestern begin construction of during Walter Dill Scott's vice-presidency?
What was the orginal name for Northwestern's Bryan Field?

plausible_answers.text: Northwestern with the University of Chicago

qas.question: What merger was proposed and rejected in 1973?
What was Northwestern one of the first seven universities in the U.S. to establish in the 1920's?
What second-ever game did Northwestern host in 1939?

context: Under Walter Dill Scott's presidency from 1920 to 1939, Northwestern began construction of an <a0_0><b5_0>integrated<b5_0/><a0_0/> campus in Chicago designed by James Gamble Rogers to house the professional schools; established the Kellogg School of Management; and built several prominent buildings on the Evanston campus, <a1_0><b6_0>Dyche Stadium<b6_0/><a1_0/> (now named Ryan Field) and Deering Library among others. In 1933, a proposal to merge <a2_0><b7_0>Northwestern with the University of Chicago<b7_0/><a2_0/> was considered but rejected. Northwestern was also one of the first six universities in the country to establish <a3_0>a <b8_0>Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps (NROTC)<b8_0/><a3_0/> in the 1920s. Northwestern played host to the first-ever <a4_0><b9_0>NCAA Men's Division<b9_0/> I Basketball Championship<a4_0/> game in 1939 in the original Patten Gymnasium, which was later demolished and relocated farther north along with the Dearborn Observatory to make room for the Technological Institute.
